lines.text: Did you know Keats?
Keats! No I didn't, and I didn't know Shakespeare or Chaucer either.
All my dead friends don't seem worth reading tonight. They always say the same things. Good things, but always the same.
Really!
Really what?
Well... really!
I want to just sit and not talk and not have to be the centre of attention all the time. You know what that's like don't you?
No.
I was just thinking about cuckoos for some reason. It's odd.
Very odd.

[to Lottie]
I hope you're not in the habit of seeing dead people, however distinguished - it's not in the best of taste! I'm sure the last thing I would want to see is my late husband Mr. Fisher crossing the road in front of my house.
That's a beautiful dress...
No I've had it a hundred years.
...but you must be very cold in it. Its easy to catch a chill here after dark. You look as if you had nothing on underneath.
I haven't.
Lady Caroline, housekeeping for a party that includes my wife - you render me speechless! You do know she's the daughter of Lord Dester, THE Lord Dester?
Ah! Well that accounts for it then. The botch-up her father made in his department during the war was a national scandal!
They never could actually prove anything.
I've wasted so much time being beautiful.
It's odd how ones mind slips sideways in a place like this.

Caroline's right. The mind slips sideways. How could I invite him? What would we talk about? The truth is... I bore him, and there's no way back. No, if you bore somebody, it's almost impossible to un-bore him.
In my day husbands and beds were very seldom mentioned in the same breath. Husbands were taken seriously, as the only true obstacle to sin.
This is outrageous, Lottie! You accepted an invitation from a friend without consulting me?
I'm consulting you now!
Well you can write her and just tell her you can't go, it's absolutely out of the question!
I can't do that!
Why not?
Because I don't want to!
